FacilityName: Valero Renewable Fuels, LLC - Fort Dodge

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Valero Renewable Fuels, LLC - Fort Dodge (Valero Renewables) is committed to the protection of our employees, the public and the environment.  This is demonstrated through our prevention program which covers areas such as operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with regulated substances.  Valero Renewables carries a written emergency response action plan to assist with accidental releases of hazardous materials. 



Processes and Regulated Substances

Valero Renewables operates an ethanol fuel production plant located in Fort Dodge, Iowa.  The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn.  The facility produces by-products known as dry and wet distillers' grain with solubles, which is used as a livestock feed as well as bio-oil which is used in the manufacture of biodiesel.  The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (natural gasoline) which may contain the following RMP regulated substances:  pentane, isopentane, neopentane (2,2-diemethylpropane), and butane.  Because of the variation in petroleum products like natural gasoline, the composition of regulated substances was determined by using the highest upper bound of each regulated substance reported on suppliers Material Safety Data Sheets and normalized to 100%.  This is a very conservative estimate.  The maximum amount of natural gasoline on-site is estimated to be 1,133,598 pounds.  The maximum amount of each regulated substance on site in the natural gasoline is estimated at 76,854 pounds of butane, 336,237 pounds of 2,2-dimethylpropane, 336,237 pounds of isopentane and 384,270 pounds of pentane.  The natural gasoline is stored in an above ground tank as a liquid and is added to the ethanol to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption.  Anhydrous ammonia is also stored on-site and used in the ethanol production process for pH control.  The maximum anhydrous ammonia store

d onsite is approximately 89,000 pounds.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Our facility has taken necessary steps to meet EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 as well as Process Safety Management requirement under OSHA.  Written procedures are in place at Valero Renewables to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are notified and trained as needed.  Our facility also maintains written operating procedures of covered processes.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as emergency and normal operations, shutdown and start-up after a turnaround.  Valero Renewables has a comprehensive training program in place which covers many topics, such as Emergency Response, Hazard Communication, Chemical Safety, and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).  The facility has a  Mechanical Integrity program for performing maintenance checks and inspections on process equipment to ensure proper operations.



Five Year Accident History

Valero Renewable Fuels has had no accidents in the last five years.



Emergency Response

Valero Renewables maintains a written emergency response action plan.  The purpose of the plan is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan addresses aspects of emergency response including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation and notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  We work with the local fire departments and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan.  The emergency response action plan is updated as necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.



Commitment to Improved Safety

The Va

lero Renewables facility has been constructed and is operated to meet existing process safety requirements.  Valero Renewables will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility.
